let's think a little bit about the data
plane side so we think about data plane
performance we're really talking about
how quickly we can get network traffic
from where it started to where it needs
to get to we can think of that in terms
of throughput the amount of traffic we
can move over a given period of time we
can also think about latency trying to
reduce the amount of time spent
processing a given network packet and
there's always going to be a trade-off
between processing a packet using CPU
time for network processing versus using
that CPU time for applications you want
to save the CPU for your
applications data plane performance is
also influenced by a lot of different
factors so the type of traffic that
you're running the size of packets
whether you're streaming or whether
things are more request response uh
whether or not you are encrypting that
network traffic there's no single
solution to optimize for all these
different things so for every given

different performance tuning that you
might want to do that said are there
things that we can do to minimize the

the amount of code that a packet goes
through the likely improvement that's
going to have on
performance so Niha already spoke a
little bit about the um the fact that
network traffic will pass through the um
network stack twice just talk a little
bit about that bring everybody up to
speed on this so in traditional
container networking we deliberately
isolate the container or in Kubernetes
case the the pod we deliberately isolate
the application from the host we put it
into a network namespace so that it is
deliberately isolated from that host but
then that means we need to connect it
and we connect it using a virtual
Ethernet connection which is running it
you know it's an extra network hop so
we've got things like ARP running
between that uh the virtual Ethernet
pairs between the pod and the
host that means that every network
packet if we imagine it's coming in
through that physical interface into the
machine it passes through the host's
network stack it then has to traverse
the virtual Ethernet connection to reach
the network name space where it goes
through the network stack again before
it reaches the
application and that was one of the
things that I think inspired the idea of
using ebpf for network traffic that
there could be things we could do to
optimize this flow
we can now use something called ebpf
host routing which you can enable in
your cluster to avoid a lot of the host
network stack so you there's a helper
function called BPF redirect pier that
can take that network packet as it
arrives into the host network name space
and switch it very quickly directly into
the network namespace for the
application where it's destined to
go and on the egress direction so for
traffic leaving the
application we can it still has to pass
over the virtual Ethernet
connection but there is a helper
function that can be used to look up the
destination for that packet
and redirect it without having to uh
pass through all of the network stack on
the host
so that as you'll see in a moment really
does improve performance quite a lot but
there is still this virtual Ethernet
connection there is still queuing
happening because packets are having to
go on a CPU per CPU queue uh to uh
traverse that virtual Ethernet
connection there will be TCP back
pressure across that connection
so there's still some overhead in this
eBPF host
routing but it is a significant
improvement so in this uh chart the
right hand bar the dark blue bar is
hosttohost networking performance uh
this is throughput and the left hand
paler bar is traditional container
networking throughput and you can see
the middle bar which is with ebpf host
routing enabled we get much closer to
host networking performance so that's a
significant improvement but you know the

uh Daniel Balkman who put Netkit devices
into the
kernel and a netkit device allows it's

has a pair so there's a pair sitting in
the network namespace for the pod and uh
a a peer a primary sitting in the host
network
namespace but the difference here is
that the host the primary is allowed to
manipulate EVPF programs inside the
network name space for the
container and that allows us
to shortcut we no longer need that
virtual Ethernet connection so we can
pick up we can have a ebpf helper
function taking that packet directly

has left the application and switch it

happening in either direction

it brings container networking
